./TOP_NEWS
Google releases Gemini CLI in open-source to run Gemini 2.5 Pro directly from your terminal
36,389 Likes
Google has released Gemini CLI, an open-source command-line AI agent that brings Gemini 2.5 Pro directly into the terminal.
It enables code writing, debugging, and workflow automation using natural language, designed for developers who need AI-powered assistance within local environments.
How does it work at a high level?
Gemini CLI connects your terminal to Gemini AI models and built-in tools. It processes commands, answers questions about your codebase, manipulates files, and automates tasks with natural language prompts.
Key features
Up to 1M token context window for code understanding
Direct codebase Q&A and editing
Multimodal input (PDFs, sketches)
Built-in Google Search grounding
MCP (Model Context Protocol) integration for tool/server extension
Scriptable and automatable for batch or non-interactive use
Open-source (Apache 2.0)
Extensible with custom commands and team settings
Free personal usage: 1,000 requests/day, 60/minute
How to use/integrate
Install via npx or npm. Authenticate with a Google account. Use CLI commands to generate code, answer questions, or automate tasks. Advanced users can use API keys or connect MCP servers.
Main limitations
Free usage is limited to individuals. Higher volume and some integrations require paid plans. Team/enterprise features may need setup.
Community Feedback
"Google is shifting devs from AI Studio to CLI because it gives Google full visibility into the entire codebase and how it evolves in real time ~ not just fragments of what they build, but the whole system and the process behind it. that’s oil for model training."
- John
"Gemini CLI is off to a bad start. What's the point of giving you free usage, when you run out of limits on the first prompt ?! Did I ask for too much all at once ? How about a cooldown period ? Strange..."
- Davide Pasca
TRY NOW
./TOP_SIGNALS
Anthropic adds an app-building feature to Claude, letting users create and share AI tools without any code.
4,193 Likes
ElevenLabs announces custom AI voice creation tool, allowing you to control tone, accent, and age.
1,538 Likes
OpenAI introduces Google Drive and Dropbox connectors to fetch data into ChatGPT Pro.
3,639 Likes
Creative Commons launches CC Signals to let dataset owners set rules for AI reuse.
839 Likes
Google includes Imagen 4 to Gemini API in paid preview, offers limited free testing in AI Studio.
729 Likes
./TOP_LECTURES
From Prompts to Systems: A Practical Guide to Context Engineering
17,829 Likes
Build dynamic systems that give LLMs the right data, tools, and instructions to complete tasks reliably. This lecture helps you move from prompt engineering to full-stack context engineering for agentic workflows.
Connect and Coordinate Agents with the Agent Communication Protocol (ACP)
1,249 Likes
Learn to build agents that talk to each other using a standard interface. Wrap them in ACP servers, connect with clients, and build both step-by-step and branching workflows.
Claude’s System Prompt - 15 Patterns for Reliable Agent Behavior
1,149 Likes
This guide breaks down Claude’s system prompt into 15 design patterns that help the AI stay consistent and aligned with user intent. It’s a structured approach to building agents through layered rules, context control, and output clarity.
./HOW_TO
Use Gemini CLI to automate tasks and build with natural language
Step 1
Install Node.js (v18 or higher) on your machine.
Step 2
Run Gemini CLI in your terminal:
npx https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli
Step 3
Sign in with your Google account when prompted.
Step 4
Navigate to a project folder or create a new one.
Step 5
Start the CLI by typing:
gemini
Now you can type text prompts to generate code, summarize files, or automate tasks.
